posts.name: Kaitlyn
posts.cooked:
I‚Äôve been doing some research into using FRC motors with other systems like Vex and Arduino lately and there‚Äôs something that doesn‚Äôt make sense to me.

CIM and Mini CIM motors use 14 gauge wire, which as I understand it is meant to handle a current of around 15-20A safely.  The stall current of a Mini Cim is around 80A, and the stall current of a CIM is around 130A.  I‚Äôd like to understand why 14 gauge wire is used, because from my understanding currents that high in a 14 gauge wire would be a fire hazard. Is it assumed that stall torque won‚Äôt be reached that frequently for this to pose a hazard? Does it have something to do with the insulation material? Any insight would be appreciated :]

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked:
While the stall current of the motors is pretty high, you‚Äôre not really supposed to run them that high most of the time. In applications that they‚Äôre designed for (RV lifts?) you really would only run them at 10-20A, and at a low duty cycle. We just abuse the heck out of motors in FRC , and get away with it because we have a low cycle count. The MiniCIM should probably be 12awg as it was commissioned by Vex, but it just may not have been considered a concern for that reason.

Don‚Äôt try and get your robot UL-listed, is all I‚Äôm saying.

posts.name: Kaitlyn
posts.cooked: Is there a reason higher gauge wires aren‚Äôt used?

You definitely should be using larger wire gauges for more powerful motors (12 gauge is standard and Krakens come with 10) but you can get away with 14 gauge for less powerful motors like CIMs and MiniCIMs, as even though we abuse the crap out of motors we only ever design for 3 minutes of use at a time so things never get too hot. 3 minutes may seem like a long time but that‚Äôs absolutely nothing compared to the durations wire amperages are rated for.

posts.name: Gus Michel II
posts.cooked: 14 gauge is enough for CIM and miniCIM because they‚Äôre fused.  Handily, the fuses double as rotor wires.

posts.name: Tristan Lall
posts.cooked:
ClearSky:

I‚Äôd like to understand why 14 gauge wire is used, because from my understanding currents that high in a 14 gauge wire would be a fire hazard. Is it assumed that stall torque won‚Äôt be reached that frequently for this to pose a hazard? Does it have something to do with the insulation material?

Good insight that the insulation material is involved. The risk tolerance of the specifying body, and the desire for a simple specification are big factors too.

The clearest constraint on wire specification is the temperature at which the insulation fails (melts, burns, distorts, chemically reacts, etc.). This is typically considerably lower than the temperature at which the metallic conductor encounters ill effects. So some 14 AWG wire can usefully carry more current than other 14 AWG wire, because of the choice of insulation material (PTFE vs. PVC, for example), even though the metallic component is equivalent.

Similarly, the thickness and thermal conductivity of the insulation matters, as does the environment in which that wire is rated to operate (there are heat transfer equations that model this). A 14 AWG wire immersed in cool flowing water vs. the same wire immersed in warm still air will have different rates of convective heat transfer, so will in effect fail at different currents because the steady-state temperature at any given current differs.

And the time for which the current is applied before the system is allowed to cool down matters. I don‚Äôt specifically know the reasoning employed for these parts, but as noted, maybe the designers felt that the time of likely operation near stall was low enough that the wires wouldn‚Äôt have time to overheat before the robot takes a break. (Or maybe, that the breaker or the internals of the motor would fail before the motor leads would.)

For specification purposes, sometimes it isn‚Äôt worth it to consider all these scenarios, and a very conservative approach is applied. This is the tendency of ampacity charts that are derived from electrical codes. It is easier to trust that someone can identify a wire based on its gauge and reference the chart, than to do the detailed calculations that are needed to prove that a given wire is safe enough in a specific installation (gauge, material, surroundings, uncertainty/consequence). In building construction, this delegates simple decision-making to the installer, which makes the whole process more efficient, even if the wire choice isn‚Äôt perfect.

In FRC , there‚Äôs no explicit statement of intent in the rules, but the strong implication is that if the wire is on a manufactured part, you‚Äôre expected to trust the manufacturer. If the wire is laid by the team, a conservative specification applies, so that there are multiple redundant reasons why fire or melting are unlikely.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
Tristan_Lall:

environment in which that wire is rated

A bundle of wires or in a tight space must be de-rated compared to a single wire in open air.

If voltage drop is a concern to OP, note that there is little difference between 6 inches of #14 vs #12 .
